text: I believe the system is always on other than for updates and such.  If the builds work on the system we can verify uptimes.  We also have some other alternatives besides using the LinuxOne system but LinuxOne is the best option we have at the moment.
do we have a build for RHEL from the Z team?
if so, we should contribute that back to Hyperledger
Currently, the build is the same for Linux for z and x86
<@U0KM61BCP> there is a RHELonZ script in the tree already, contributed by <@U10Q62R8X>
I think in devenv
awesomesauce
I'm on mobile, otherwise would send link
no need thanks
yep, I was trying to make the build on z as 'friendly' to x people as possible, so it looks very similar
similar to what happens when you run `vagrant up`

re: linuxone.. those systems get retired after 120 days I think.. but I know the sysadmins, we can remove that expiry for a particular image (or images). Since Dan is our build guy, I propose we hijack his image :slightly_smiling_face: I will work with Dan offline about removing the restrictions, but yes, nothing should stop us today from using his system to try out jenkins on z!
<@U10Q62R8X>: to be clear, this would be a permanent build pipeline - not just trying out jenkins
most definitely!
ok, just being sure we are on the same page
we have precedent of assigning linux one images to open source project build farm.. so its a 'battle' somebody already won

<@U1BC5NF2S|bramwelt> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/bramwelt/F1D9NS9RU/-.txt|Untitled> and commented: <@U14FUGATW>: This should be all that's needed to connect Jenkins to the Z system.

file.name: -.txt
file.title: Untitled
file.preview:
useradd -m -G docker -s /bin/bash jenkins
mkdir /home/jenkins/.ssh
mkdir /w
echo "ssh-rsa  hyperledger-jenkins@jenkins.hyperledger.org" > /home/jenkins/.ssh/authorized_keys
chown -R jenkins:jenkins /home/jenkins/.ssh /w
file.preview_highlight:
useradd -m -G docker -s /bin/bash jenkins
mkdir /home/jenkins/.ssh
mkdir /w
echo "ssh-rsa  hyperledger-jenkins@jenkins.hyperledger.org" > /home/jenkins/.ssh/authorized_keys
chown -R jenkins:jenkins /home/jenkins/.ssh /w

initial_comment.comment: <@U14FUGATW>: This should be all that's needed to connect Jenkins to the Z system.

text: Then to connect Jenkins all we should need is a public ip or hostname.
Will you need a userid and password as well as hostname/IP?
we need a hostname/IP as well as a jenkins user created as that snippet shows
though that docker group may not be needed if there's no docker on the z image
<@U14FUGATW>: We shouldn't, since we have you to ping for installing deps, etc. :wink:
ok.
the setup script that I wrote, installs all the dependencies, including docker... since I was being lazy, I did everything as root.. not a completely insane idea, since that was 'single user' VM..
still.. something that is 'fixable'.. dependency installation will still need privileges though.. I was wondering about that part of the build
do you expect the build machine to have all the dependencies installed? or does the build do it (i.e. within a fresh vagrant?)
we use vagrant to create build an image and then snapshot it. The dynamic builders (slaves) are then booted from that snapshot
we don't boot directly using vagrant in the build environment
it's just being used as an image creation platform
hmm.. interesting.. I was having a debate with the sysadmins the value of creating a 'snapshot' of a hyperledger image that people can then create vm's out of
it is a kvm after all...
we use the upstream cloud images as our base boot
'upstream cloud images'.. sorry, will need a translation :slightly_smiling_face:
essentially we're using vagrant similar to the design goals of packer, except we need to actually boot the system to do the creation, which is why we use vagrant instead of packer

ubuntu cloud images: <https://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/>
centos cloud images: <http://cloud.centos.org/centos/7/images/>
the appropriate base image is loaded into our OpenStack environment. We then use that as the base image that we boot vagrant on top of and configure
The basic process is documented here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree;f=vagrant;h=c3eb6c2c8179b20d295ca8d7d846d722daeca49c;hb=HEAD>

that process produces our snapshots. We then hook them into Jenkins using the OpenStack Cloud provider plugin. With a UserData script that clones the ci-management project and executes the init_system.sh found here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree;f=jenkins-scripts;h=68f5408d7b690f789224e38f2777d76d4a313ec2;hb=HEAD>
between the snapshot and the init script we have fully working slaves
that are easy to update
The ip address is 148.100.107.97
The SHOULD be good to go.  :grinning:  jenkins is created along with .ssh directory and key file, docker group, and /var/hyperledger
Hmm, can't seem to connect.
Seems that SSH is running, and I can talk to it.
<@U1BLNM9DE>: I was curious about your statement "we need to actually boot the system to do the creation, which is why we use vagrant instead of packer"
It seems to me that both native Vagrantfile and packer methods for producing vagrant images boot a system
can you elaborate on where the limitation was that you found?
(thats not a criticism, I am just intellectually curious)

ghaskins: I'll admit something before I continue too much further with this discussion. When we were first evaluating how best to create images I didn't know about packer. Second, I haven't looked that far into it since discovering it since Vagrant works for all of our use cases and has provider plugins for all the different clouds where we use this design. When I last looked at packer it didn't have provider plugins for rackspace, libvirt or openstack. That could well have changed
ah, i see
in terms of booting a system, I think they are similar
in terms of backend support, you are probably right about that
the rackspace and openstack providers are most critical to our use cases
it makes the most sense to use packer if you want to support more than one basic type of image
but if you can achieve that in other ways (such as within a Vagrantfile) it might be easier to just use native facilities

ghaskins: if you look at the Vagrantfile in use for hyperledger you'll see it's actually pretty basic. Yes, it does some OpenStack specific configuration, but it wouldn't be hard to add in provider bits for libvirt or virtualbox backends for extra configuration related to those VM systems. outside of that it's, just calling configuration scripts and then 'resealing' the system so that a snapshot can be taken
cool, sounds reasonable
<@U1BLNM9DE> notes that the current Vagrantfile design is the result of over 1.5 years of use with this usage pattern across multiple LF Collaborative Projects
actually, that's probably closer to 2.5 years now...
like I said, don’t interpret that as criticism, I was just curious what you ran into
my only experience with packer was on this project and it was a mixed bag
that's fine. I didn't interpret it as criticism. I actually got the same question from one of our other recent CPs at about the same point in their life as this
but as I just said, that decision was actually made 1.5 - 2.5 years ago, so the reasons are a bit cloudy to me now, even though I made the decision!
Could I please have a webhook added to `hyperledger/fabric` for `<https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/github-webhook/>`?
we also need to add `jenkins` as service in github
tell me how
<@U1BC5NF2S>: correct me if I am wrong?
ry: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/settings/hooks>
Oh, right there is a 'service' hmm. let me see if I can find the configs for that
<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/settings/hooks/new?service=jenkins>
<@U11HH3P7Y|ramesh> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ramesh/F1DB0F6LB/capture.png|Capture.PNG>
bramwelt: there are two options, jenkins/git and jenkins/github. I assume we want the latter?
ry: correct
<@U1BC5NF2S>: it’s installed with the URL you gave above
ry: Thank you very much!
ramesh: is there another jenkins instance I should hook?
no. this  should suffice `<https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/github-webhook/>`

Awesome! Looks like we have builds being triggered from Github by merges from master: <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric/job/fabric-github-merge-x86_64/8/> Still working out kinks with the build slave...
Awesome
<@U0UHG4VP1>: Would you kindly add (as a manual webhook) `<https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/ghprbhook/>`? Please, and thank you!
